> >    Have a missed a choice?
> 
> Yes, the ones I mentioned on my previous response.  Factories for
> instance.  

I think Jason was including the factory approach in the
'globals/static' category, especially since you say:

> The Factory could be globally
> accessible, if that makes sense or pass it in at creation time. 

I think the question he was getting at (or at least one that I run
into) is how to create static factories that do useful things (like
hand out database connections), but still use mockObjects for unit
testing.

Using threadlocals seems like an interesting approach, although I'll
admit I kind of feel bad for doing it.  Can someone think of specific
problems with this approach, as it otherwise seems like a good idea: 
My unit tests get to specify the static factories for their test
environment, and it avoids stepping on the toes of other tests. 
Furthermore, my test can configure the factories in a number of ways,
testing a number of possible configurations.


> Let's say I have a DBQuery that obviously needs a DatabaseConnection
> to do much of its work.  The query doesn't need the connection for
its
> full life-span, only for the short period of time in which to run 
> against the DB, perhaps the rest of the time is doing maintenance
work 
> or creating Record objects to represent a row in the DB, etc.  So, I 
> make a Factory (in this case probably a pool) available from which
the 
> query can grab a connection when it needs it and then give it back.  
> The connection too has things that it may need only for a short
period 
> of time and can give them up -- i.e. a Prepared or CallableStatement.
 
>
> It can get the statement from a factory it has access to and then
give 
> it back when it's done.

Right -- how do you use MockObjects with that?

-Kevin
